title: 108_hr4943
content: The Act titled "Pima County Land Adjustment Act" allows for a land exchange involving Ironwood-Moore, Empirita-Simonson, and Sahuarita properties in Arizona. The Pima County Land Adjustment Act authorizes a land exchange involving the Ironwood-Moore, Empirita-Simonson, and Sahuarita properties in Arizona. Las Cienegas Conservation, LLC will convey the Ironwood-Moore and Empirita-Simonson properties to the Secretary of the Interior in exchange for the Sahuarita property. The boundaries of the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area will be adjusted to include the Empirita-Simonson property. The land exchange must be completed within 90 days of meeting title standards. The Pima County Land Adjustment Act authorizes a land exchange involving the Ironwood-Moore, Empirita-Simonson, and Sahuarita properties in Arizona. Las Cienegas Conservation, LLC will convey properties to the United States, with appraisals needing approval. Cash equalization payment will be made if land values are not equal, following the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. The Pima County Land Adjustment Act allows a land exchange involving properties in Arizona. Cash equalization payments received will be deposited into a separate account for land acquisition and resource management in southern Arizona. Water rights agreements are required for the exchange to proceed. Simonson relinquishes water rights to Pima County in section 17. Neal Simonson limits withdrawal on Empirita-Simonson property to 550 acre feet per year. Secretary prohibited from constructing roads providing access outside Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. Environmental review required for exchange. Las Cienegas Conservation, LLC must reimburse the Secretary for environmental review costs. The conveyance of Sahuarita property will be reviewed under the Endangered Species Act. SEC. 3. Acquisition and conveyance of Tumamoc Hill property. Upon the expiration of the 30-day period after the enactment of the Act, the United States will acquire the Tumamoc Hill property, subject to existing easements. The State of Arizona will receive compensation equal to the negotiated or court-determined value of the property. The State of Arizona or the Secretary may seek court determination of just compensation for acquiring Tumamoc Hill property. Upon payment by Pima County, the Secretary will convey all rights to the property within 60 days. Within a 60-day period starting from Pima County's payment to the State Land Department, the Secretary will transfer all rights to the Tumamoc Hill property. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATION OF LAND EXCHANGES. The Secretary must ensure that title to exchanged lands complies with the Attorney General's title standards. Corrections to legal descriptions can be made by mutual agreement. Appraisals for land values will be determined by the Secretary through an appraisal performed by a qualified appraiser in accordance with federal standards. The Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice and the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 set deadlines for completing appraisals and environmental reviews within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, various properties are defined including the Empirita-Simonson property, Ironwood-Moore property, Sahuarita property, Secretary, and Tumamoc Hill property. The State of Arizona owns approximately 290 acres of land in sections 9, 10, 15, and 16 township 14 south, range 13 east, Gila and Salt River Base and Meridian, excluding about 30 acres of landfill.
